;香港记者协会表示可以向法院申请豁免如果下个月政府的禁令申请获得批准，将在新闻报道中使用抗议歌曲“荣耀属于香港”。

;

;该协会已指示其律师致函律政司，以获取更多信息该组织周三表示，有关政府申请的信息。

;

;政府正在寻求禁止所有形式的抗议歌曲及其衍生歌曲。

;

;法院禁令如果获得批准，将防止任何有分裂主义或煽动意图，或试图违反国歌法的人“广播、表演、印刷、出版、销售、要约销售、分发、传播、展示或复制”歌曲，包括在互联网上。;

;港人自由发声抗议歌曲禁播：律政司司长

;

;法庭预计7月21日开庭审理此案。

;

;协会表示：“我们还明确表示，我们可能会考虑请求法院允许干预诉讼程序，并申请将新闻报道视为豁免 [如果获得禁令]，以保护记者。”

;

; “该协会想强调的是，它无意发布或上传歌曲《荣耀归香港》。”

;

;法院在 2019 年的裁决中承认了新闻自由的重要性。豁免警方发布警员个人详细信息的禁令。

;

;该禁令旨在打击当年反政府抗议活动中针对警员的人肉搜索企图。

;

;香港抗议歌曲重回平台，创作者发誓要捍卫自由

;

;律政司司长林廷国周二呼吁那些不同意政府申请的人挺身而出，参与法律程序，以便双方可以“在法官面前陈述我们各自的论点”。

;

;同一天，包括人权观察和第十九条在内的 24 个国际人权组织敦促苹果、谷歌、Meta、Twitter 和 Spotify 就向香港法院提出法律上诉以反对禁令投标的公开信。

;

;拟议的禁令是在几项海外体育赛事的组织者播放抗议曲调而不是国歌“March of the志愿者”。

;

;“荣耀归香港”在谷歌“香港国歌”搜索结果中名列前茅。

;美国已对缅甸国防部和两家银行实施制裁据美国财政部网站周三报道，东南亚国家的军政府将以外币购买武器和其他商品。

;

;这些银行被命名为缅甸对外贸易银行 (MFTB) 和缅甸投资商业银行 ( MICB），为缅甸政府接收和传输外币，其中包括为军政府筹集大部分收入的国有企业。

;

;东盟主要成员因批评而跳过泰国主持的缅甸会谈

;

;缅甸深陷军事政变和对亲民主抗议活动的致命镇压所导致的暴力和不稳定之中，在此期间，数百人被杀，数千人被捕，并普遍指控任意拘留、强迫失踪和酷刑。

;

;专家表示，对银行的制裁虽然没有针对天然气项目，但天然气项目是 2021 年 2 月夺取缅甸控制权的军方的主要收入来源，可能会影响军政府为其战争提供资金的能力族群和叛乱。

;

;运动组织 EarthRights International 在 2 月的一份报告中说，这两家银行是“缅甸政府的外汇库”，现在处于军政府的控制之下。

;

;“军政府依靠EarthRights International 表示，用外币购买许多产品，包括喷气燃料、小型武器生产零件和其他无法用缅元购买的物资。

;

;“因此，对 MFTB 的制裁MICB 可以为切断军政府获取外汇的渠道做出重大贡献，特别是如果与强有力的执法相结合的话。”

;中国民航业仍处于亏损状态，一直是最艰难的行业之一在冠状病毒大流行期间受到打击，并呼吁政府提供支持，因为过去三年北京的零 Covid 政策的幽灵继续困扰着这个世界第二大经济体。

;

;国家控制的斗争尽管是最先从大流行中复苏的行业之一，但与其他服务业的快速反弹形成鲜明对比，加剧了市场对正在失去动力的经济复苏不均衡的担忧。

;

;行业领袖在中国航空运输协会主办的研讨会上表示，与外国同行不同，中国航空公司面临着复杂的国内外挑战，包括来自中国庞大的高铁网络的日益激烈的竞争以及日益复杂的地缘政治气候(CATA) 上周。

;

;“到年底，中美航线的航班数量将难以实现显着增长，”CATA 周一发表的一篇文章称.

;

;“未来几年受地缘政治因素影响，日韩航线前景不容乐观。”

;

;协会指出，不利因素阻碍由于地缘政治紧张、贸易摩擦、海外机场关键资源不足和签证办理等原因，国际航线是最赚钱的业务板块，国际航线的恢复进程。

;

;签证申请的等待时间可能会延长至该协会表示，5 月份出港航班数量已恢复到 2019 年同期水平的不到三分之一。

;

;为什么中国的 C919 用了 15 年才造出首个商业航班？

;

;“由于海外机场容量限制，欧洲和东南亚航线也受到限制，”CATA 补充道。

;

;中美之间的航班数量也仍然大大落后于大流行之前的水平——本周早些时候美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯和中国外交部长秦刚讨论了这个问题。

;

;从 5 月 30 日开始，两国之间的直飞航班数量中美之间从每周300多个直飞航班骤降到每周24个往返，最终增加到每周24个往返。

;

;但大量往返中美的旅客仍需依赖中转航班.

;

;由于燃油价格上涨、人民币贬值等其他经营压力，中国航空公司二季度整体继续亏损。

;

;强劲复苏，超过 4 月和 5 月大流行前的水平，因为人们渴望旅行，这与其他服务行业的反弹一致。

;

;为期三天的端午节国内航班预订量根据在线航班服务应用程序 Umetrip 发布的一份报告，截至周一，周四开始的航班增加了两倍多。

;

;“[然而，] 高铁改道对民航产生了显着影响航空运营，特别是中短途航线，”CATA 补充道。

;

;京沪航线是世界上最繁忙的航线之一，其客运量尚未恢复到原来水平与2019年同期相比。

;

;与许多陷入困境的中国行业一样，该协会建议将往年实施的支持政策延长至2024年底。

;

;措施包括提供持续的金融和财政政策支持，同时积极寻求延长民航特别紧急贷款。

;

;它们还涉及发行价值 2000 亿元人民币（279 亿美元）的债券，该协会指出，其中包括退税等其他措施。

;

;中国三大航空公司——中国国际航空公司、中国东方航空公司和中国南方航空公司——报告称去年合计亏损人民币 1087 亿元（151 亿美元） ，根据他们的年度报告，由于北京严格的零 Covid 政策扰乱了国内和国际旅行。

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯 (Antony Blinken) 进行重要的修补关系访问后不久发生口水战分析人士表示，尽管双边关系几乎不可能进一步恶化，但与中国的贸易往来进一步证明华盛顿无法“言出必行”。

;

;这是在美国总统乔拜登将矛头对准中国国家主席习近平提到了据称中国“间谍气球”引发的对峙，这促使布林肯推迟了他 2 月份的访问计划。

;

;“[中国国家主席] 习近平非常生气的原因，就当我击落那个装有两辆装满间谍设备的车厢的气球时，他是否不知道它在那里，”正在寻求连任的拜登周二在加利福尼亚州的一次筹款活动中说。

;

;“这对独裁者来说是一个极大的尴尬，因为他们不知道发生了什么。”

;

;美军击落了气球，中国称这是一辆气象监测车2 月 4 日，在飞机漂入美国领空几天后，发生了“不可抗力事故”。

;

;中国外交部迅速回击拜登的言论，称其为“政治挑衅”。

;

; p>;

;“美方有关言论极其荒谬和不负责任，严重违反基本事实、外交礼节和中国的政治尊严，”外交部发言人毛宁说。

;

;拜登的表态刚刚发表就在布林肯在北京会见习近平的第二天，美国频道 MSNBC 播出了对这位美国高级外交官的采访，他在采访中表示，只要事件不再重演，“那个 [气球] 章应该关闭”。;

;目前尚不清楚最新的交流是否会影响今年 11 月在旧金山举行的下一届亚太经济合作组织 (APEC) 峰会上拜登与习主席会面的前景。

;

;但是，分析人士表示，拜登的言论不太可能使本已糟糕的双边关系恶化，因为中国对拜登剩余任期内情况改善的期望很低。

;

;东西桥创始人兼总裁 Koh King Kee 表示，国际关系学者的学术网络，双方之间几乎没有政治信任。

;

;“北京对拜登领导下的中美关系没有幻想，但愿意保持沟通渠道畅通，共同建设“护栏”，以避免双方可能最终导致任何不幸事件的误判，”Koh 说。

;

;他补充说，中国对明年双边关系改善的希望很低。

;

;Koh 表示，拜登的言论也与习近平和布林肯对稳定关系的积极承诺形成鲜明对比，这表明总统与其政府之间存在脱节。

;

;“美国官员，包括国务卿，经常不得不澄清拜登的即兴评论，”Koh 说，他指的是 9 月份在 CBS 的一次采访中，美国总统发誓要派兵保卫台湾——白宫后来收回了这些言论。

;

;据清华大学“一带一路”战略研究院外交政策分析师兼研究员 Zoon Ahmed Khan 称，北京长期以来一直观察到华盛顿的行动与其表达的合作意愿之间的不匹配。

;

;“中国意识到美国无法说到做到，因此，尽管它是一个重要的经济伙伴，但北京知道期望拜登政府有更好的言辞是不现实的，”汗说。

;

;在 2020 年的竞选审判中，拜登曾称习近平是“暴徒”，并誓言要领导国际努力“向中国施压、孤立和惩罚中国”。

;

;“临近选举季，很明显，拜登政府正在安抚国内选民，对他们来说，当前和直接的威胁是中国及其日益增长的全球影响力，”汗说，并补充说，如果拜登要软化或缓和他的反华言论，他就有失去国内和国际支持的风险。

;

;美国目前的情绪要求拜登加强他对中国的强硬立场，尽管北京要求华盛顿在潜在的交流中保持尊重，Khan 说。

;

;“实际上，对于拜登政府明确表示他们愿意与中国接触对光学很重要，但同样他们必须在盟友面前展示自己是‘自由世界’的领导者。”

;

;可能如果乔·拜登连任，美中关系真的会改善吗？

;

;新加坡南洋理工大学外交政策助理教授 Dylan Loh 表示，拜登的言论不会削弱本已疲软的双边关系。< /p>;

;“美国总统倾向于即兴发挥，因此可以在这种情况下看出这一点，”Loh 说。

;

;这种“停止-开始，前进-他补充说，敌对大国之间“落后”的接触方式将成为常规。

;

;习近平和拜登去年 11 月在巴厘岛 20 国集团峰会期间举行的会晤产生了积极成果，包括布林肯访问的前景中国是近五年来美国国务卿首次进行此类访问。然而，一个月后美国对台军售再次引发紧张局势，拜登在气球事件后推迟访问。

;

;Dewey Sim 补充报道

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Trade war: Proposed US legislation puts China’s cross-border e-commerce sector in cross hairs, hitting Temu and Sheinhttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3224896/trade-war-proposed-us-legislation-puts-chinas-cross-border-e-commerce-sector-cross-hairs-hitting?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.21 22:00;
;;

;随着中国跨境电子商务市场的增长，得益于对于像 Temu 和 Shein 这样的廉价电子商务应用程序，一些美国政府代表正在推动取消对中国托运人有价值的贸易豁免，此举可能会损害他们的价格优势。

;

;引入了两党法案上周向美国国会表示，赞助商表示将针对中国的电子商务行业，修改每天允许数百万低价值中国货物免税进入该国的“漏洞”。

;

;例外有问题的，被称为最低限度规则，如果物品被运送给个人消费者，则免除价值 800 美元或以下的进口关税。专家表示，如果废除中国进口商品，这可能会影响从中国发货的快时尚巨头 Shein 和 PDD Holdings 的 Temu 等在线购物平台的利润。

;

;“这将增加运营跨境电子商务公司的成本，使他们在全球竞争中处于不利地位，”杭州市场咨询公司 100ec.cn 专注于跨境电子商务的分析师张周平说。

;

;在政治审查期间，Shein 与中国竞争对手 Temu 一起在都柏林设立了新办事处

;

;作为美中贸易战的一部分，除了现有关税之外，还对大量中国进口商品征收额外 25% 的关税2019 年。Zhang 表示，如果 Temu 和 Shein 必须支付这笔费用，它可能会通过提高价格转嫁给美国消费者。

;

;据专注于中国的市场研究公司 Daxue Consulting 的营销总监 Allison Malmsten 表示，该规则的取消可能会削弱广泛的价格优势，这些优势帮助 Temu、Shein 和其他中国托运人从亚马逊等美国托运人那里抢走了业务，从而在中美快时尚领域创造了公平的竞争环境。

;

; Malmsten 补充说：“De Minimis 一直是 Shein 和 Temu 维持其产品极具竞争力的低价的关键漏洞。”

;

;亚马逊中国电子商务应用程序 Temu 本月早些时候进行了具有竞争力的价格检查，称该公司没有达到其公平定价标准。这家美国巨头表示，其资格标准确保它不会将价格与“有问题的”市场进行比较，包括产品可能是假冒产品的平台。

;

;Temu 在其网站上表示，它有“严格的上市政策”或销售侵犯第三方商标、版权或专利权的产品”。

;

;Shein 和 Temu 的低价也是两个竞争对手之间激烈竞争的结果，一些专家质疑他们是否。然而，预算定价帮助这两款应用程序自推出以来越来越受欢迎并在全球范围内扩张。 Temu 目前是 Apple 应用商店在美国最畅销的应用。

;

;拼多多和 Temu 的所有者在对中国应用的审查中开设都柏林办事处

;

;Temu 和 Shein 最近在海外取得的成功在中国跨境电子商务领域强劲增长的背景下，2022 年进出口额首次​​突破 2 万亿元人民币（2806 亿美元），比 2021 年增长 7.1%，国家新华社周日报道。

;

;报道补充说，2022年中国跨境电商出口目的地中，美国市场占比超过三分之一。

;< p>;虽然在通货膨胀率上升的情况下，更便宜的中国购物替代品在美国变得流行，但进口产品越来越引起美国官员的愤怒。据美国提议修改最低限额规则的法案，这一变化不仅是为了实施贸易关税，而是针对非法货物的流动。

;

;除免税外，最低限额货物还可以进入

;

;4 月份的一份美国联邦报告指责 Shein 和 Temu 存在数据风险，并质疑他们使用最低限度豁免进口非法物品，例如那些侵犯知识产权或违反美国《2021 年维吾尔族强迫劳动预防法》(UFLPA) 的行为。

;

;在报告中，Shein 表示其低价格并非由于使用强迫劳动。

;

;“微量漏洞是对美国竞争力、消费者安全和基本人权的威胁”，美国国会议员 Earl Blumenauer 说，他上周重新提出了旨在修订微量法的《进口安全与公平法》。该法案曾于去年提出，目前尚不清楚它是否会在本届会议上获得通过。

;

;“它使美国企业处于竞争劣势，同时向美国消费者提供无疑有害的产品，”Blumenauer 补充道。 /p>;

;Temu 和 Shein 没有回应置评请求。

;

;根据 Blumenauer 的提议，随着国会两院引入的版本，从中国和俄罗斯进口的产品将失去微量。它遵循由参议员比尔卡西迪领导的单独的最低限度互惠法案，该法案同样会拒绝中国获得贸易豁免，但包括降低美国最低限度门槛的条款。

;

;然而，尽管存在潜在贸易关税的威胁北京电子商务咨询公司海豚创始人兼首席分析师李成东表示，在美国，中国的供应链在短期内对特木和 Shein 仍然有利。

;

;在价格背景下，李说，已经很低了，25% 的增幅相对较小。例如，Temu 提供多种廉价商品，一些最便宜的家居装饰品价格低于 1 美元，一些小工具只需几美元。

;

;便宜的替代品不多李补充说，通过跨境预算购物平台销售的产品，越南和印度的供应商目前无法与中国供应链提供的价格相提并论。

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 22:20:02 +0800 Antony Blinken’s China trip seen as positive but could put some US allies in ‘precarious position’https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3224919/antony-blinkens-china-trip-seen-positive-could-put-some-us-allies-precarious-position?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.21 22:00;
;;

;美国国务卿本周的北京之行可能在某种程度上让人们安心China's neighbours over their rivalry, but observers say long-term concerns remain.

;

;Beijing and Washington agreed during Antony Blinken's two-day visit to hold more high-level talks – the latest effort to halt a downward spiral in relations that has left many nations in a tough position over which side they support. Such exchanges had been largely frozen after the US shot down a suspected Chinese spy balloon in February.

;

;Yan Xuetong, dean of the Institute of International Relations at Tsinghua University, said the talks would be welcomed by the region.

;

;“The greatest worry for neighbouring countries is a war between China and the US,” he said. “As long as there's no outbreak of war between them and their contradictions and even competition are handled in a peaceful way, these countries will feel that they can cope.”

;

;China and the US both wanted to appear willing to listen to the concerns of other countries rather than continue being confrontational, according to Chen Xiangmiao, an assistant research fellow at the National Institute for South China Sea Studies in Hainan.

;

;“Both sides want to ease the anxiety of countries in Asia and even in Europe, as the intensifying competition between China and the US has emerged as a thorny challenge in their own bilateral ties with many countries,” Chen said.

;

;“The trip also sent a signal to the world that there is no zero-sum game between China and the US, and that they're taking responsibility for regional peace and stability.”

;

;James Downes, head of politics and public administration at Hong Kong Metropolitan University, noted that Blinken and senior Chinese diplomats had met for longer than scheduled.

;

;“From a PR perspective, the recent talks look positive,” he said. “Renewed positive ties between China and the United States are important for the European Union within the current global economic climate, as the EU seeks to continue its post-Covid economic recovery.”

;

;But the talks would not ease the concerns of some EU countries over issues like Beijing's foreign policy in the Indo-Pacific region. “Politically, the EU appears to be aligning more closely with the US in response to China's growing geopolitical assertiveness,” Downes said.

;

;North Korea slams 'begging' Blinken for trying to 'press and restrain' China

;

;While Beijing and Washington have pledged to keep their rivalry from turning into an actual conflict, a possible confrontation could be dangerous for countries like Japan – a US ally that sees China as a top security threat, according to James Brown, an international relations professor at the Tokyo campus of Temple University.

;

;Ties between Beijing and Tokyo are strained over their wartime history and territorial disputes, but the neighbours have close links and China is Japan's most important trading partner.

;

;“For this reason, excessive hawkishness from Washington and talk of decoupling is not welcomed in Tokyo. The last thing Japanese policymakers want is a regional crisis,” Brown said.

;

;“In this context, Japan will welcome Blinken's trip to Beijing. It takes some of the heat out of the relationship and maintains channels of communication, which may be vital to avoiding a future crisis.”

;

;During the talks, China and the US agreed to find common ground on issues such as the fight against fentanyl trafficking and increasing direct flights between the two countries.

;

;But there were no breakthroughs on contentious issues like Washington's support for Taiwan – the self-ruled island Beijing claims as its own – and technology export restrictions against China, human rights or the restoration of military communication channels. Those channels have been suspended since then-US House speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taiwan in August last year.

;

;Li Mingjiang, an associate professor with the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, said the Blinken trip could lead to “a bit of stability” in US-China relations and “limited cooperation” on areas such as climate change, food security and public health.

;

;That would be positive news for Southeast Asia – home to nearly 700 million people in countries that have close trading ties with China and deep security relations with the US.

;

;“However, leaders in these regional states will also understand that US-China relations are still very fragile and they will continue to face pressure to take sides,” Li said.

;

;Why China still refuses to resume military dialogue with US

;

;But for some US allies in the region that are vulnerable to a potential Chinese backlash in economic, military or diplomatic areas, Blinken's China trip could leave them in “a precarious position”, according to Lee Seong-hyon, a senior fellow with the Houston, Texas-based George HW Bush Foundation for US-China Relations.

;

;Lee noted that under President Joe Biden, the US had taken on an alliance-centred strategy to counter China.

;

;“It appears as though Washington persuaded and even pressured its hesitant allies into confronting China on the front line,” Lee said. “However, when their allies eventually consented to partake in the anti-China campaign, Washington abruptly extended an olive branch to China, leaving them in a precarious position.”

;

;Washington's allies could be disappointed if it appears to be “needy and not approaching China from a position of strength, and even potentially retreating from its competition with China”, Lee added.

;

;“Ironically, therefore, Blinken's peace-offering mission to China may have inadvertently fuelled an increased sense of uncertainty in US-China relations, amplifying the impulse to hedge between them instead of definitively siding with Washington.”

;

;Additional reporting by Orange Wang and Hayley Wong

;The Chinese aircraft carrier Shandong sailed through the Taiwan Strait on Wednesday, just two days after US Secretary of State Antony Blinken concluded a fence-mending visit to China.

;

;While both sides described his talks with senior officials – including President Xi Jinping – as constructive, Blinken failed to persuade his Chinese hosts to agree to resume high-level military dialogue between the two countries.

;

;The US has been pushing for a channel of communication between senior commanders to help reduce the risk of miscalculations and misunderstandings amid rising tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

;

;According to Taiwan's defence ministry, the Shandong kept to the west side of the median line on Wednesday when it sailed through the Strait from north to south.

;

;Meanwhile, 19 PLA planes, including a Y-8 anti-submarine aircraft and a Y-8 electronic warfare plane, and five warships were spotted southwest of the island on Tuesday.

;

;Beijing views Taiwan as a renegade province to be brought under its control, by force if necessary.

;

;PLA aircraft carrier sails through Taiwan Strait: island's defence ministry

;

;Most countries, including the US, do not recognise Taiwan as an independent state but oppose any attempt to change the status quo by force.

;

;During Blinken's visit, Wang Yi, Xi's top foreign policy adviser, told him that Beijing has “no room for compromise” on Taiwan, describing it as a core interest.

;

;Cross-strait tension has been mounting in recent years as Washington steps up arms sales and political support for the island, while Beijing intensifies its military activities.

;

;Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, there have been increasing calls for Washington – which is legally bound to help the island defend itself – to do more to boost its military capabilities.

;

;Beijing cut off inter-military dialogue in retaliation for then US House speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to the island in August – something it regarded as a serious breach of its sovereignty – and also conducted its largest-ever military exercise around the island.

;

;Taiwan kicks off annual Han Kuang war games with eye on latest PLA threats

;

;The Shandong reportedly left its home port in Hainan at the time of the exercise, although did not directly take part in the drill.

;

;But in April, the carrier participated in another large-scale show of force around Taiwan, known as “Joint Sword”, in response to Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen's meeting with senior politicians, including the current Speaker Kevin McCarthy, during a visit to California.

;

;In April's exercise, the Shandong and its escort warships were deployed in the waters east of the island, practising area denial in the event of an intervention by foreign forces.

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 21:50:02 +0800 University council trio hit out at Hong Kong lawmaker’s demand it pays HK$700,000 cost of private member’s bill to reduce proportion of insiders on bodyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3224927/university-council-trio-hit-out-hong-kong-lawmakers-demand-it-pays-hk700000-cost-private-members?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.21 21:49;
;;

;Members of Chinese University's governing body have hit out at Hong Kong lawmaker Tommy Cheung Yu-yan and claimed he ignored an earlier consensus and pushed ahead with his own proposal to restructure the institution's council through a private member's bill.

;

;The three members, in a letter sent on Wednesday, also criticised Cheung, who also sits on the university council, for a failure to seek approval from the body for his bill.

;

;The joint letter also expressed “strong discontent” with Cheung after he asked the university to pay more than HK$700,000 (US$89,419) to cover the costs of the proposed legislation.

;

;They also complained that Cheung, also a member of the Executive Council, the government's key decision-making body, had an “arrogant and hostile” attitude at university council meetings.

;

;The private member's bill to amend the Chinese University Ordinance was designed to downsize the council membership from 55 to 34 and increase the proportion of external representatives so they would outnumber internal ones 2:1.

;

;It also has a provision to raise the voting threshold for the appointment of the university vice-chancellor from two-thirds to three-quarters of the council votes and increase the number of members chosen by the government.

;

;The bill was also backed by other lawmakers on the university council, Bill Tang Ka-piu and Edward Lau Kwok-fan.

;

;The letter opposing the move, posted on the Facebook page of one of the complainants, Kelvin Yeung Yu-ming, was addressed to council chairman Professor John Chai Yat-chiu.

;

;Copies were sent to university vice-chancellor Professor Rocky Tuan Sung-chi and Legislative Council president Andrew Leung Kwan-yuen.

;

;Yeung is also the chairman of Chinese University's convocation, a statutory body made up of all its graduates.

;

;The other two co-authors of the letter were Dr Barbara Kwok Pik-lin, and Enders Lam Wai-hung. The trio were elected to the council from among the convocation members.

;

;“It is nothing personal. We just hope to raise our concerns and draw the attention of the council chairman and relevant stakeholders to the matter,” Lam said.

;

;Hong Kong lawmaker wants university to cover costs of private bid to revamp council

;

;“Mr Cheung cannot just push ahead a version of reforms he has devised without any proper consultation.

;

;“We have had a task force to look into the issue and there was comprehensive consultation. We think the views presented in the consultation should be respected.

;

;“Even if Mr Cheung's bill has gone to the Legislative Council, it can still be amended and changes can be made before it is passed.”

;

;The trio also accused Cheung of acting “haughtily” by ignoring the recommendations in a previous report endorsed by the council on the restructuring of the body.

;

;The letter said Leung had “demanded the university settle the costs incurred” in the preparation of the bill and added “we members express strong discontent”.

;

;“It is his private bill. The council has not discussed or approved it. It is only natural he himself should be responsible for the costs,” Lam insisted.

;

;The trio agreed a publicly-funded institution should be monitored by Legco and the public.

;

;But the letter said: “We cannot tolerate that Cheung, as a council member, has repeatedly destroyed the atmosphere of meetings with his arrogant and hostile attitude.”

;

;“The matter will be dealt with by the council. In accordance with the principle of confidentiality, the university will not disclose the discussion at the council meetings,” a university spokesman told the Post.

;

;Reforms push for university in Hong Kong after 'appalling' protest handling

;

;Cheung's assistant said he was not prepared to comment on the letter.

;

;The private bill is expected to be introduced to Legco for a first and second reading on June 28 at the earliest.

;

;The proposed amendment was seen as the pro-establishment camp's response to the controversial reappointment of Tuan, who will stay on as university vice-chancellor until 2026.

;

;Tuan was accused by some Beijing loyalist figures of being sympathetic to students involved in protests during the 2019 social unrest.

;

;Tang has argued that it was “very reasonable” the university should pay for the costs of the bill, but some fellow council members spoke out against it.

;

;They said the bill was an initiative by the lawmakers and had not been discussed or approved by the body.

;

;A task force report backed by the university in April agreed that the council should be reduced to a maximum of 34 people, but still with a higher proportion of internal members than Cheung's proposal.

;

;It also called for two lawmaker members to sit on the council instead of three.

;

;The task force also recommended that the threshold for electing the vice-chancellor and provost should be raised from about 66 per cent to 75 per cent of council votes.

;

;The consultation conducted by the task force, which got 880 responses from interested parties, including staff, students and graduates, also found massive opposition to several elements of Cheung's proposal.
